Award.AwardTitle: Reconciling substrate specific differences in the carbon isotope excursion marking the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Model predictions and long-range forecasts for future climate change are partly based on studies of geologic records of past global warming events. One such global warming event occurred ~55.8 million years ago and is referred to as the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM). Study of geologic records around the world has shown that surface temperatures warmed 5-8Â°C, biochemical processes were altered, and the global biosphere was profoundly perturbed during this time. However, the most distinctive hallmark of the PETM is a precipitous decrease in the stable carbon isotope (13C/12C) ratios of terrestrial and marine carbon-bearing materials. This carbon isotope excursion (CIE) has been documented at numerous locations across the globe, and its ubiquity signals the rapid release of massive quantities of isotopically light carbon (12C) into the ocean-atmosphere system. The source of this carbon is still debated, but the most parsimonious explanation invokes the dissociation of massive quantities of sedimentary methane hydrate along continental slopes. The fact that this ancient global warming event is closely linked to a major perturbation to the global carbon cycle uniquely qualifies the PETM as an analogue for future climate change driven by current societal practices.

A key piece of evidence for estimating the amount of carbon emitted during the PETM is the magnitude of the CIE, yet it has long been recognized that different carbon-bearing substrates yield different CIE magnitudes. For example, the CIE reported from terrestrial records (soil nodules and land plant remains) is about twice as large as indicated by measurements of marine sediments. This discrepancy is vexing because gases are readily exchanged across the air-sea interface so that the physiochemical state of the surface ocean should equilibrate with the atmosphere on time scales virtually instantaneous by geologic standards. Hence, the magnitude of the CIE in terrestrial and surface-ocean records should be similar, yet this is not borne out by published records.

The vast majority of marine PETM records are derived from the stable isotopic compositions of tiny (<1 mm) calcite shells grown by planktic foraminifera, an extant group of amoeboid protists with a rich fossil record. The preponderance of planktic foraminiferal shells in deep-sea sediments has made them a preferred substrate for studies using geochemical analyses to reconstruct past ocean/climate change. However, a problem plaguing such records is that post-depositional processes on the seafloor can alter the original chemical compositions of foraminiferal shells, thereby biasing stable isotope records used to reconstruct past climate conditions like those that prevailed during the PETM

At the Wisconsin Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometer (WiscSIMS) laboratory, novel in situ techniques have been developed for measuring stable isotope ratios in tiny (~10 micrometers) targets in calcite samples. This approach permits the identification and analysis of subdomains inside foraminiferal shells that are less affected by chemical alteration and therefore provide a more accurate record of past climatic conditions. Currently, these stable isotope measurements cannot be performed by any other technique. First results from a pilot study indicate that the CIE magnitude recorded within these well-preserved subdomains in planktic foraminiferal shells is actually twice as high as previously reported and thus highly congruous with the CIE magnitude in terrestrial records. This project focuses on obtaining a more accurate measurement of the CIE magnitude. Determining the true magnitude of the CIE is important because it will (1) better constrain the amount of carbon emitted, (2) provide a more realistic testing ground for assessing the viability of proposed sources of the carbon input, (3) improve our ability to gauge climate sensitivity to greenhouse gas forcing, (4) help identify feedback mechanisms within the climate system that either amplify or attenuate global warming, and (5) make it possible to better calibrate biotic (terrestrial and marine) responses to environmental change driven by rapid carbon input. This project will benefit the graduate education of a young female scientist, and provide infrastructure support for the WiscSIMS laboratory where transformative, cutting-edge analytical technologies are being developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of funds provided by Award 1405224 were used to support (1) a gifted female graduate student who successfully completed her Ph.D. and has taken a post-doctoral position at the University of Colorado-Boulder, (2) advance the career of a promising, young scientist who has since taken a Research Professorship with Columbia University, and (3) a Senior thesis completed by an outstanding female undergradate student who is now in the process of applying to graduate programs at different universities. A portion of the funds was also used to pay for instrument time and technical support in the WiscSIMS Laboratory, which is a National Facility housed in the Department of Geoscience at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The main focus of our collective research is the development and application of a new, state-of-the-art analytical technique (secondary ion mass spectrometry or "SIMS") to perform high-precision geochemical measurements on extremely tiny samples at ultra-high (~3-10 micrometers) spatial resolution.

Our first goal was to test the accuracy of these SIMS measurements. This was achieved through a series of experiments where carbon isotope (d13C) ratios were measured by both SIMS and conventional techniques. This comparative study revealed no inter-instrumental differences in the d13C ratios, thereby confirming the accuracy of our SIMS measurements.

Having confirmed the accuracy of our SIMS measurements, the second goal was to apply this new analytical technique to the measurement of d13C ratios in minute, micrometer-sized domains within individual microfossils (forams) whose shells are about the size of an individual grain of salt. To this end, we targeted fossil foram shells preserved in deep-sea sediments that record ocean-climate conditions during an ancient global warming event called the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum, or PETM.  We targeted foram shells from the PETM for the following reasons: (1) Earth surface temps warmed by 5ºC during the PETM, (2) PETM greenhouse conditions profoundly altered the complexion of both land and marine ecosystems, (3) carbon isotope (d13C) ratios measured from foram shells record a "carbon isotope excursion" (CIE), indicating that PETM warming was intimately linked to the release of massive quantities of carbon into the ocean-atmosphere system, and (4) the PETM is widely considered to be an ancient analogue for future climate change being driven by human activities. It is with this background information in mind that we note that knowing the size (scale) of the CIE recorded by fossil foram shells is vital to ascertaining the amount of carbon emitted into the ocean-atmosphere system during the PETM. We need to know the size fo the CIE because it can provide constraints on the sensitivity of climate and ecosystems to rising atmospheric CO2 levels. Thus, the PETM represents a natural laboratory for testing the effects of rising CO2 concentrations.

Unfortunately, measuring the size of the CIE associated with the PETM is complicated by chemical reactions within deep-sea sediments that typically alter the original d13C ratio of fossil foram shells. We emphasize that is it abundantly clear that the carbon isotopic composition of the ocean-atmosphere changed dramatically in response to carbon emissions during the PETM, but accurate measurement of the size of the CIE marking this perturbation remain challenging. This is where our new SIMS technique can be applied to obtain accurate measurements of the original d13C compositions of foram shells, thereby enabling us to measure the true size of the CIE. This is the case because certain micrometer-sized domains within fossil foram shells are more resistant to this form of post-mortem alteration, and the utlra-high spatial resolution of our SIMS analyses permits us to measure the d13C ratios of these relatively unaltered domains. The findings of our SIMS-based study reveals that the true size of the CIE recorded by foram shells is nearly twice as large as that usually measured with conventional analytical techniques. This discovery provides a more accurate estimate of the CIE magnitude, which in turn matches the size of the CIE recorded in other age-equivalent materials such as carbonate nodules preserved in fossilized soil horizons and land-plant oragnic matter. Thus, our revised estimate for the CIE can be used in computational models to assess the sensitivity of Earth's climate, hydrological cycle, and biota to rising CO2 levels in the atmosphere.

All data and results generated with Award 1405224 will be made available to the scientific community and general public through publication in widely distributed, peer-reviewed journals over the next two years (2018-2019). The data will also be made available to all interested parties by electronically archiving it with NOAA's World Data Services for Paleoclimatology/PANGAEA (https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access/paleoclimatology-data/contributing). On behalf of all those involved in this research (students, researchers, technical staff and myself), I express our sincere graditude to the U.S. taxpayers for supporting our research and furthering the careers of several young, promising scientists.
